workshop.name: In-class problem: rocket launch
workshop.intro: This will be our first attempt at working a problem in class in groups.  The problem has been designed to be quick to do, and straightforward to mark since you will be marking it.
workshop.instructauthors:
Objectives

  1. Students will write down knows and unknowns.

  2. Students will solve for unknowns using UAM equations.


A model rocket takes off from the launch pad with a large, constant, upward acceleration that is unknown. After 2.50 s it runs out of fuel at a height of 425 m above the launch pad. Let y = 0 on the launch pad and define up as positive for y.

First write down the knowns and unknowns for the problem, using the axes specified in the question.

After you have written the knowns and unknowns, find the acceleration of the rocket while its engine was firing.
workshop.instructreviewers: You will assess several (probably two) submissions by other people.  Follow the marking  guide.  The marking guide should be detailed enough that you won't have to use much judgement.
workshop.conclusion: Thanks for participating in this activity.  Note that you will have received two marks.  One mark will be for your submission.  The other mark is for the quality of feedback you gave to the submissions you were asked to assess.  The grade for the quality of assessment is found by comparing your assessment with the assessments of others who marked the same submission.  If you all agree on the grade then you get a perfect mark for your assessment.

workshopform_accumulative_dimension.description:
They should have started by writing down the knowns and unknowns.  They should be

yi = 0, yf = 425 m, viy = 0, vfy = ?, ay = ?, Δt = 2.5 s.

Did they get all of this correct?

2 marks - all correct

1 mark - 1 or 2 errors

0 marks - more than 2 errors

Don't be picky about minor issues of notation.  If they just called the velocity components vi and vf, or u and v, that's fine.  The point is, do they know the values of each variable.  What they called them is a matter of choice.  But if their choices of symbols are so odd (and unexplained) that you don't know which symbol stands for which variable then give no marks for things that you don't understand.

Now they will need to pick an equation which will allow them to solve.  They need to choose

\( \Delta y = v_{iy} \Delta t + \frac{1}{2}a_y \Delta t^2 \)

Again, don't worry if they have written it with other symbols.  But they should have, somewhere, written down the equation that they are using, in a reasonably understandable form.  If they went straight to a "wall of numbers" without writing down their equation symbolically then they should not get this mark.

Wrote down the correct equation, symbolically (i.e. without numbers substituted in).  Different choices of symbols are OK as long as the equation is clear - 1 mark

Didn't write down the equation at all, or only wrote it down with numbers substituted in - 0 marks

Now they should, first solve for the variable that they want (\(a_y\)).  Then they should substitute in numbers.  They might have substituted in numbers first, then solved.  That's really bad practice, but we are not going to give lower marks for it.  People who did that have already punished themselves by having to work harder to get an answer.

Solving, they should get

\( a_y = \frac{2\Delta y}{\Delta t^2} = \frac{2 (425 \, \textrm{m})}{(2.5 \, \textrm{s})^2} = 136 \, \textrm{m/s}^2 \)

Rearranged and substituted correct numbers into correct places - 1 mark

Final answer correct - 1 mark

examplesubmission.title: Sample, motion diagram and x vs. t graph
